LEAD: In ancient times when I undertook to advise two young men on significant matters, I told them firmly they should never undertake to marry anyone - well, settle down with anyone - if they had not first taken a long coach train trip with her. For two years I had traveled to college in Minnesota in coach and in that time I had discarded any number of prospective dates, some potential roommates and a few heroes.

LEAD: To the Editor: The article about traveling in Europe with children omitted one of the most interesting ways to see Europe: camping. We traveled extensively with our children (the youngest was 8) on two occasions, and each time we camped, the first time for six weeks, the second for a month. We have pitched our tents in Oslo, Copenhagen, The Hague, Munich, Lucerne, Vienna and the Bois de Boulogne in Paris.

She was the third wife and widow of the playwright Eugene O'Neill, the survivor of a dark and tempestuous 24-year marriage.

LEAD: Saab-Scania AB of Sweden has announced it will close its bus manufacturing plant here this summer, citing reduced demand for city buses as a reason.

LEAD: Recently I was invited to select the worthy entries for a juried exhibition to which anyone with a photograph and five dollars could submit. This is called ''jurying'' a show, but to my mind it amounts to being prosecutor, judge and jury simultaneously. Not exactly a fair trial, mind you, but then no one who enters such things really expects objectivity to rule.

LEAD: In her Feb. 14 Opinion Page article, Phyllis Elston correctly pointed out that I opposed S. 426, which granted the Legislature authority to endorse or reject the pending State Development and Redevelopment Plan. She also correctly pointed out that I was the only one of five committee members opposed to the bill.

Momentarily it was frightening.

LEAD: Look, say the Presidential candidates: Our allies prosper while the United States strains to provide far more than its share of the common defense. The allies must be forced, the refrain goes, to do their fair share. The theme already has been reduced to shorthand: burden-sharing. Like most slogans, this one reverberates with simplicity, power - and ignorance.

The Rev. William Lloyd Fox Jr., a Unitarian minister, officiated.

LEAD: An Israeli judge said last week that ''there is no punishment in the rules of man that is severe enough'' for John Demjanjuk, whom an Israeli court found to be a Nazi death camp guard who helped torture and murder thousands of Jews during World War II. The judge sentenced Mr. Demjanjuk to death by hanging.

LEAD: South Koreans, blessed and maybe also a bit cursed with a limitless capacity for political surprise, put their democratic progress to a tough new test last week and wandered into wholly uncharted territory. It was anyone's guess whether the journey would turn out well.

LEAD: Saudi Arabia rejected early today a proposal that would have opened the way to unprecedented cooperation between the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and nonmember independent oil producers.

LEAD: International trade is a chief concern of many trade association executives. The newest twist in such programs is the ''generic'' export trading company, introduced last year by the National Machine Tool Builders Association. This company is generic because, rather than specifically naming the partners, its export trade certificate - which allows joint trade activities to foreign markets - covers the association's entire membership, including new members as they join, said Charles G.

LEAD: Older people struggling along on limited incomes are becoming increasingly aware that reverse mortgage loans will provide them with monthly sums - $500 on average - to help meet the costs of remaining in their homes.

LEAD: For his cello recital at the 92d Street Y on Thursday evening, Eric Bartlett presented a pair of New York premieres sandwiched between pieces by Beethoven, Schumann and Brahms. Larry Bell's ''The Black Cat,'' based on Poe's story, proved the more unusual, if less impressive, of the two - a monodrama or dramatic recitation accompanied by illustrative music.

LEAD: The euphoria of bloodlessly ousting a dictator a little over two years ago has worn off, and the grumbles have resumed. Practically every major question in the Philippines now has to be answered with ''maybe, too soon to tell.''

LEAD: No law now requires the airlines to advise the public of the experience and training of pilots or the conditions of the particular planes in which they are about to fly. Perhaps if such information were required to be posted at the check-in desks, airlines might focus more on the quality of their service.

LEAD: IN Edward Lear's well-known rhyme, ''The owl and the pussycat went out to sea in a beautiful pea-green boat.'' They came back, however, in Bill Manhoff's 1964 farce, ''The Owl and the Pussycat,'' which is being revived by the Long Island Stage Company.

LEAD: Brighton is known as the princely resort, and for once the boosters' claim is not hyperbole. The Prince Regent's Royal Pavilion is as splendid and exotic as Kublai Khan's pleasure dome, and the Regency squares and terraces built for his courtiers and aristocratic friends are a contrast in cool elegance.

LEAD: DR. HAROLD J. RAVECHE, the next president of Stevens Institute of Technology, says that the nation was built on a foundation of strong education and that ''hands-on experience and studies'' can improve the quality of its future leaders.

LEAD: To the Editor: My first and only experience with Now Voyager was nowhere near as rosy as the piece would have newcomers believe. Having booked a trip to Sydney three months in advance, I was informed three days before my departure that the company I was traveling for had no freight to send and my services were not required.

LEAD: All the images about the withering of American industry these last few years seemed a little truer here and felt a little sadder. Bethlehem Steel and Mack Trucks, the big-name companies that once built the industrial centers of eastern Pennsylvania, were shrinking down or pulling out. Sometimes, it seemed as if the companies had turned against their towns, testing them to see whether they could take it.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The sprawling grid of tract developments and shopping malls that is Fort Collins, Colo., eventually peters out miles from the city's old cow-town core amid winter-yellow fields and rolling, snow-streaked prairie. Something like half of this land, split-levels and sagebrush alike, is bought and sold through a single Fort Collins real estate company known as The Group Inc.
LEAD: Handmade Heritage FOR many, their heritage was in the assorted shopping bags and baskets they carried into the large room at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.

LEAD: First Meal for Condor Chick Molloko, the first California condor conceived in captivity, dined on minced mouse at San Diego's Wild Animal Park. Page 27. Workers Stress the 3 R's In this age of high technology, American companies are trying to correct employees' deficiencies in reading, writing and mathematics.
LEAD: TO the considerable relief of hundreds of Westchester high school seniors and their counselors, April is over and college acceptances have been received.

LEAD: EVERY afternoon, the routine is the same. Dave Winfield leaves his New Jersey home, steers his luxury foreign car across the George Washington Bridge and through the congestion of the Bronx, and parks in the players' lot at Yankee Stadium. He acknowledges the cheers from the dozen or so fans who have waited patiently outside the entrance to the park.

LEAD: When 9-year-old DeeDee, from New York City, went on her first visit to an apple farm in Maine, she was amazed. She never knew, she said, that apples grow on trees. She thought they arrived in plastic bags. Her enlightenment came by way of the Fresh Air Fund, which offers poor inner-city youngsters free vacations in the country.

LEAD: At St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Oceanside, L.I., Mary Elizabeth Abele, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Abele of Baldwin and Southold, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael David Makurat, the son of Mrs. Thomas M. Makurat of Harwich, Mass., and the late Mr. Makurat. The Rev. Thomas F.

LEAD: Smart wrappings for fall add warmth as well as luxury to wool suits and dresses. They are rectangular scarves bordered or appliqued with such furs as fox, sable, mink, Persian lamb or chinchilla.

LEAD: The marriage of Lola Blanton Neill, the daughter of Lucy B. Neill and Julian F. Neill, both of New Orleans, to Kendrick Thomas Kelly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kendrick A. Kelly of Chappaqua, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Although he is Mayor of the largest city in the country, Mayor Koch may not attend the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta in mid-July. It would be the first time in the memory of veteran politicians that a Democratic Mayor of New York did not go to the convention.

LEAD: The leader of a P.L.O. faction, buoyed by the Palestine Liberation Organization's reconciliation with Syria, has announced plans to increase attacks against Israel from Lebanon. At the same time, Israeli troops have been conducting an extensive search in southern Lebanon for suspected guerrillas.
LEAD: GROWTH in the western part of Monmouth County contributed significantly to the county's overall 7.8 percent population increase from 1980 to 1986, according to state and local officials.

LEAD: At the Asbury United Methodist Church in Crestwood, N.Y., Lorraine Ann Mohan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Mohan of Milford, Mass., was married yesterday to James Francis Murray, a son of Mrs. James P. Murray of Tuckahoe, N.Y., and the late Mr. Murray. The Rev. William S. Shillady performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Twenty-eight hours after leav-ing New York, I've sat on two airplanes, shook from side to side in the back seat of a car, putted across a river on a canopied skiff, stood on a ramshackle wooden bus and climbed a rutted, red-clay hill. All of this has brought me, at last, to the top of a bluff in a remote coastal town of Bahia, Brazil.

LEAD: THE votes have been counted - all 4,879 of them - and the results are official: on Friday, three local authors and an illustrator will receive the 1988 Washington Irving Children's Book Choice Awards at the Westchester Library Association's annual luncheon at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown.

LEAD: Feeling Lovable Floyd Patterson demystifies boxing and shows us what it's actually like. Here he tells Gay Talese how it feels to be knocked out. This is from ''Reading the Fights,'' edited by Joyce Carol Oates and Daniel Halpern (Holt).
LEAD: THE MAN WHO INVENTED SATURDAY MORNING And Other Adventures in American Enterprise. By David Owen. 215 pp. New York: Villard Books. $16.95.

LEAD: Deadbeat Tenant Question: Recently I agreed to let an acquaintance stay in my apartment until next August while I work in Los Angeles. We agreed in a letter that she would pay half of the rent and the utility bills.

LEAD: The Light Fantastic: It's Cause Enough

LEAD: WHEN Ernest Hunter started collecting art during the Depression, he was one of few in his Greenwich Village neighborhood who had a steady income, from working at a local speak-easy. Many artists who lived nearby were desperate to make a fast dollar and knew that Mr. Hunter couldn't say no to their paintings and etchings.

LEAD: The Government today ordered an NBC News television correspondent to leave the country after he reported that Jordan is a repressive society. The reporter, Rick Davis, was given a week to leave.

LEAD: Gretchen Reinhard Siebel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Siebel of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to John Brian Mannix, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul S. Mannix of Arlington, Mass. Edward W. Horne, an East Hampton Town Justice on Long Island, performed the ceremony at the Siebel home in Amagansett.
LEAD: NOTHING TO DECLARE Memoirs of a Woman Traveling Alone. By Mary Morris. 250 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

LEAD: Susan Melville Hunt and the Rev. Mark Hollingsworth Jr., the son of Caroline J. Hollingsworth of Concord, Mass., and the late Mr. Hollingsworth, plan to marry in July, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hunt of Cambridge, Mass., have announced.

LEAD: AS OUR species claimed dominion over the earth, we pushed incalculable numbers of plants and animals up to and over the edge of that dark abyss called extinction. We blame our unenlightened, selfish, exploitive ancestors who killed off the Labrador duck, passenger pigeon and great auk and who brought the bison and whooping crane right to the brink.
LEAD: Former Gov. Jim Rhodes of Ohio had a favorite trick in campaign speeches: He would take out his wallet, slap it on the lectern, and shout, ''That is where elections are won.''

LEAD: CONGRESS has followed the New Jersey Legislature's lead and enacted legislation that challenges industries to release their grip on chemical information. Industries' response to this challenge will reflect how much they have learned, in the decade since Love Canal, about dealing with communities.

McKay of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit in Salt Lake City, and the Rev. Gary M. Gallun, a Unitarian minister, officiated.
LEAD: Louise Brooke Riskin and Eugene Francis Messinger were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York yes by Rabbi Harold Swiss.
LEAD: A man and a woman were killed in Manhattan early yesterday when a speeding car careered into them as they crossed the street, the authorities said.
LEAD: BALANCED BUDGETS & AMERICAN POLITICS By James D. Savage. Tables. 350 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $27.95.
LEAD: TOURISTS and people looking for a country style of life near a scenic lake have combined to make this community the fastest growing town in Maine.
LEAD: It wasn't Jesse Jackson, Presidential candidate, on the hustings today. It was Jesse Jackson, adviser, offering the Democratic front-runner unsolicited counsel on how to lead.

LEAD: Eric Floyd and Akeem Olajuwon settled their private feud by taking it out on the Dallas Mavericks today. In the process, they pulled the Houston Rockets even in their three-of-five first-round series with the Dallas Mavericks.

LEAD: Elizabeth Joy Wingate, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Wingate of Hamden, Conn., was married last evening to Joel M. Hausman, the son of Mrs. Irving Hausman of San Francisco and the late Rabbi Hausman. Rabbi Herbert Brockman performed the ceremony at Temple Mishkan Israel in Hamden.

LEAD: Tom Clancy, insur-ance agent turned supernovelist, grips the wheel of his newest toy, a four-wheel-drive GMC Jimmy, as he shows a visitor around the 80 rolling acres overlooking the Chesapeake Bay where he plans to build a dream house to replace the dream house he built several years ago.

LEAD: IN the carrying-coals-to-Newcastle department: the first shipload of American-made Honda Accord coupes left Portland, Ore., for export to Japan last month. Honda, the fourth-largest automaker in the United States, plans to export 4,000 Accords to Japan this year.

LEAD: LARGE crowds gathered across the street and movie extras earning $50 a day stood patiently in their designated positions while a plethora of cameras, lights, cables and other movie-making gear filled the parking lot at the Uptown Garage in Meriden last Monday and Tuesday.
LEAD: Going to the beach used to be sim-ple. You headed off with a towel, a paperback book and a bottle of suntan lotion under your arm.

LEAD: Last Tuesday Nathan Lewin, a partner in the law firm of Miller, Cassidy, Larroca & Lewin, argued before the Supreme Court in favor of keeping the gray markets open. The court is expected to decide on this question before it recesses in July. Mr. Lewin spoke with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about how the consumer benefits from gray markets and why the gray markets should not be closed.

LEAD: The nonstop controversy over Edwin Meese 3d demonstrates the indispensability of an independent attorney general committed to the rule of law. Voters must insist that the Presidential candidates specify right now the criteria they would use to choose a nominee.
LEAD: By her daughter's account, Stella Nickell put cyanide in pain relief capsules to poison her husband of 12 years in an effort to gain as much as $176,000 in life insurance benefits.

LEAD: A man accused of burglary became the first inmate to escape from New York City's prison barge when he crawled to freedom yesterday through an air-conditioner opening behind the barge's kitchen, city corrections officials said.

LEAD: An article in the Arts and Leisure section on April 17 about the pre-Broadway tour of ''Macbeth'' and an article in some copies of the main news section on March 6 about the United States visit of Prince Charles misidentified a theater in Pittsburgh.
LEAD: An American nuclear-powered attack submarine ran aground off Fox Island near here late Friday and stayed stuck for 10 hours, until four Navy tugs pulled it free at high tide this morning.

LEAD: The month ended suddenly, and when it did, Dave Winfield was there again, smiling about another incredible night and another Yankee victory.

LEAD: WITH the solemn intensity of an Englishman clutching his umbrella, or a Japanese with his camera, Americans carry plastic -credit cards. Real men may not eat quiche, but real Americans do shop, and in our materialism, we determine our worth by what we own.

LEAD: There rrxhare some similarities between George Bush and Martin Van Buren, the last man to be elected President while serving as Vice President: Both spent most of their lives on the public payroll, and, as Vice Presidents, both were regarded as confidants of their Presidents.

QxB?! because 10 N-Q5, Q-Q1; 11 P-QB4 is strong, Black being unable to play 11 ... P-N5? because of 12 Q-R4!

LEAD: ''Here is the heart of Samaria,'' said Ron Nachman, standing on a windswept hilltop near the old Arab city of Nablus. ''Here is the future.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TO meet the growing need of working parents for day care for their children, states are increasingly playing a role. Local governments, too, are taking a hand. But many believe that, as with public schooling, only the Government can insure affordable, dependable programs nationwide.
LEAD: THE cost of going to the dentist has always been painful and is often considered an additional insult to needing treatment in the first place.
LEAD: The men's varsity heavyweight crew from Pennsylvania defeated Navy, Harvard and the Severn River this morning to gain possession of the Adams Cup for the second time in the last three years.

LEAD: Dissidenten, a band from West Berlin, has its ears turned to North Africa. The songs the group brought to S.O.B.'s on Tuesday, opening a two-night stand, used Moroccan-style melodies, with modal scales and microtonal inflections, in settings that moved from Africa toward Europe as the early set progressed.

LEAD: Every Presidential election year provides a forceful reminder that a glass can be portrayed as half empty or half full. In 1988, the battery of figures Republicans are marshaling emphasize what the White House calls the ''significant and good news'' about the economy; Democrats are trying to accentuate the negative.

LEAD: It is not any race horse who can achieve a 7-for-7 lifetime victory record over different racetracks, at various distances, against the best horses in the East. Along with these accomplishments, intelligence, honesty and heart are necessary for greatness. My 1988 Kentucky Derby choice embodies all of these qualities.

LEAD: During the last six months, the job market in the Northeast has flourished as steadily as it has over the last several years, flouting the predictions of economic pessimists who read the October stock market collapse as a signal of impending decline. Unemployment figures are expected to remain low, and wages may rise as companies scramble to find able help.
LEAD: MARK JACKSON'S lower lip was sticking out, more in pain than defiance. He had caught a stray elbow during the horror sequence, and two of his front teeth were feeling loose.
LEAD: With the amnesty program of the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 due to expire Wednesday, large numbers of aliens are now coming forward to apply in the New York region.
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL

LEAD: To what extent mathematics and bridge go together is an interesting question. There are indeed some high-level mathematicians who are terrible bridge-players and vice versa, but there is surely some correlation. Perhaps there is a mathematical-bridge potential that may lie partially dormant.
LEAD: Mandatory rationing of water will begin Sunday for 2.1 million residents of the San Francisco area after two consecutive dry winters and a failure of voluntary efforts.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Stone of Washington of the engagement of their daughter Nancy Rachel Stone to Joel Benjamin Poznansky, the son of Drs. Jack and Dulcie Poznansky of London.

LEAD: Marguerite F. Karter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Karter of New York, and Howard Rory Elisofon, a son of George Elisofon of Brooklyn and the late Sylvia Elisofon, were married last evening at the Explorers Club in New York. Rabbi Eugene Lipsi performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Montview Boulevard Presbyterian Church in Denver was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Anne Sidney Allison, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Clark Allison of The Hague and Plandome Manor, L.I., to David Black Park, the son of James B. Park of Denver and Mrs. Kenneth F. Lewis of Old Lyme, Conn.

LEAD: Patricia Leigh Brown has done a service by piercing the myth of fly-fishing's most elite connotations (''An Angler's Rites of Spring,'' March 27). It's an activity that can be as simple or complex as one desires. My fly-fishing guide service in the Lake Tahoe area has attracted the ''eclectic'' cross section she mentions: a microsurgeon who was enthralled to learn that a ''triple-surgeon'' is a standard angling knot, a sheet-metal worker, a printer, a fisheries biologist on a busman's holiday, an advertising executive and an M.B
LEAD: Dr. Lisa Sue White, an oral surgeon in Methuen, Mass., and Dr. Barry Stephen Paul, a dermatologist in Boston, were married last night at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston by Rabbi Amiel Wohl.

LEAD: I stand in awe of my body, this matter to which I am bound has become so strange to me. I fear not spirits, ghosts, of which I am one . . . but I fear bodies, I tremble to meet them. What is this Titan that has possession of me? Talk of mysteries! - Think of our life in nature, - daily to be shown matter, to come into contact with it, - rocks, trees, wind on our cheeks!

LEAD: James McCracken, the most successful dramatic tenor yet produced by the United States and a pillar of the Metropolitan Opera in the 1960's and 70's, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan.

LEAD: The marriage of Nancy Gail Warshauer, the daughter of Mrs. Emanuel S. Warshauer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and the late Mr. Warshauer, to Gregory Elliot Mendel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mendel of Ocean, N.J., took place last evening at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains. Rabbi Mark Winer officiated.

LEAD: IN less than three years, the Boston Post Road Stage Company has emerged as a small theater of audacity and intelligence. With ''On the Verge,'' which concludes the company's second full season, it may have come up with its most challenging, offbeat play yet.

In February, a friend returned from a month in Canton. LEAD: The Reagan Administration's new approach to Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is perceived in Panama as a risky move that may not resolve the country's political crisis.
LEAD: Vice President Bush's march toward the Republican nomination is carrying him into a predicament that few men in his position have overcome.

LEAD: Private Terms is a thoroughly professional race horse who does whatever is necessary to win. He has also carried the Derby weight (126 lbs.) to victory in the Gotham and the Wood Memorial. ALAN SHUBACK New York
LEAD: When stock prices collapsed in October, program trading was criticized as one of the chief villains in the financial drama.

LEAD: IT was the search for a new building in which to expand a long-established family-owned plumbing supply business that eventually led to the development of a new business project, the $9 million Building and Design Center at Yorktown, said Jonas Weiner, one of the owners of Best Plumbing Supply and a principal in the development of the center.

LEAD: NITA LOWEY, a former assistant secretary of state in New York, entered the Democratic race for Congress last week, the third member of her party to seek the 20th Congressional District seat held by the two-term Republican incumbent Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi.
LEAD: Two former employees of an asbestos removal company have been indicted in the slaying of the company's president, who was shot to death in the driveway of his Rumson home.
LEAD: Lar Lubovitch's new ''Of My Soul'' is an awkward dance. It is fascinating, as well. Usually, in dance, awkwardness is undesirable.

LEAD: The arrival of May and the impending end of school put the nation in the grip of motorized wanderlust. But if your ''radio'' is still the one that came with the car from the factory, it may well require an updated sound system before it can be considered roadworthy in a musical sense.

LEAD: Q. I recently painted my living room. The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places. It has been painted many times before. How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

LEAD: HE hasn't even seen the doctor, but Jimmy Connors, who has been nursing a sore foot for months, has the scenario mapped out. The doctor will tell him he needs surgery and suddenly his career will be over. ''I'm finished,'' he said. ''I'd have to take six months off, then I'm 36 years old. Then it would take me six months more to get back in decent shape.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There are buildings that are known for the architect who designed them, and there are buildings that are known for the client who commissioned them, and the new headquarters of Domino's Pizza Inc. falls firmly in the second category. It is no disrespect to Gunnar Birkerts, the architect of this unusual, nearly half-mile-long office building, to observe that his profile is somewhat lower than that of Tom Monaghan, the founder and chairman of Domino's, a national chain of pizza stores specializing in home delivery.

LEAD: On a rather foreboding block of the Lower East Side, amid art dealers and drug dealers, rats and real-estate speculators, dancers are dancing, actors are acting and R. Jeffrey Cohen, the 30-year-old director of the R.A.P.P. Arts Center, has grand visions for his new multi-disciplinary arts organization.

LEAD: Roy Medvedev, the independent historian whose fiercely critical books about the Stalin era have won world acclaim but have been banned in his own country, was praised this week by an official newspaper for his work and his role as a voice of conscience.

LEAD: The electric power industry is watching uneasily as the Long Island Lighting Company tries to fight off a hostile takeover by the public agency created for the purpose of reconsidering Lilco's existence.

LEAD: In ''Robin's Band,'' an outspoken little musical set in the near future, there is never any question of who is good and who is evil. The good guys, costumed in colorful improvised outfits that make them resemble refugees from a postpunk version of ''Hair,'' are assorted street people who have been dispossessed of their homes by greedy real-estate barons and forced to live in ''the undeveloped zone'' of an unnamed major city.

LEAD: Living beside one of New York City's bridges may not seem the sanest idea right now, but David H. Ward says the Brooklyn Bridge and 4-10 Water Street, which he is converting into co-ops, have been coexisting serenely for more than a century. The 1860 warehouse is just south of the 1883 span. ''If you stood on the edge of the bridge and dropped a screwdriver it wouldn't fall on the roof,'' Mr.
LEAD: Three hemophiliac brothers who doctors say were probably exposed to AIDS through blood-clotting agents are suing two pharmaceutical companies that processed the product.

LEAD: David Packard never wanted to take his fortune with him, but he wants to be very sure of how it is used. Mr. Packard, the 75-year-old board chairman of the Hewlett-Packard Company, last week disclosed his plans for transferring his $2 billion fortune to the David and Lucille Packard Foundation, making it the fifth or sixth largest in the country.
LEAD: New York City's streets may not be squeaky clean, but they may receive a bit of sparkle with a new asphalt called ''glasphalt'' - 20 percent glass.

LEAD: The king of the mini-series is tired and yearning for his beach house in Hawaii. ''I don't handle complexity very well,'' Richard Chamberlain says. ''I'm very simple-minded. It's so simple in Hawaii -watching the sunset is the big event of the day.''
LEAD: The Government yesterday barred older Boeing 737's like the Aloha Airlines plane torn open over Hawaii from flying above 23,000 feet until they are subjected to a stringent new inspection.

LEAD: Brimfield, Mass., is a serene New England village, the sort you might like to drive through on a Sunday. It's a one-street town with a triangular village green, a few red barns, some not too curlicued Victorian houses, a Congregational church, a blue and yellow Sunoco station, a grocery store with posters proclaiming the week's specials, a pizza parlor, a granite-faced bank and Francesco's Italian Ristorante, with a couple of cars out front.

LEAD: Last Sunday, municipal officials and war veterans in this Communist-governed town west of Paris went to the monument to the dead to remember those deported to Nazi extermination camps. LEAD: Iraq has successfully test-fired a new surface-to-surface missile with a range of 560 miles, far enough to hit Iranian targets in the Strait of Hormuz and increase pressure on Iran's oil traffic through the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: America's gray markets, also called parallel importation, are now big business. These markets arise when clever traders purchase well-known brand-name products from foreign suppliers and sell them to other domestic middlemen who are not part of the manufacturer's normal distribution chain. The practice is most likely to occur when currencies change value both substantially and quickly.
LEAD: I would appreciate an opportunity to answer recent letters to the Long Island editor that misrepresent my point of view.

LEAD: Never mind if they're per-forming in a plush Broadway theater or a spidery little loft in SoHo. Never mind if they've been directed by Peter Brook or the assistant stage manager's senile great uncle. There's still a special thrill of anticipation when a major actor or actress tackles a great Shakespearean part.

LEAD: The article on campus drinking [ ''Campus Drinking: Colleges Confront 'Issue of the 80's,' '' April 10 ] presents some interesting information on how local colleges are struggling to regulate alcohol consumption among their student bodies, but the analysis lacks sufficient breadth to cover how the colleges are failing today to provide much meaningful education about drug and alcohol abuse.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration has toughened its drug enforcement by allowing the Coast Guard to seize any boat or ship on which even a small amount of contraband is found, Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley said today.

LEAD: The Mets prevailed and were happy. The umpires survived and were just plain relieved. Pete Rose, whose team lost, said he was injured and incensed and somewhat unsure of what his options for protesting the game were.

LEAD: Phyllis Lamhut's new ''Utopia,'' which opened on Thursday at the Westbeth Theater Center (151 Bank Street), will not disappoint those who have come to admire this veteran choreographer's comparatively recent forays into the darkness of history and the heart. It is a powerful dance that boasts an equally powerful and ambitious score by Ben Hazard and stunning performances from its six leads that are alone worth a trip to the theater.

LEAD: A California businessman, charged last year in the fatal shooting of his companion, has been arrested as a suspect in a 1981 robbery and shooting death in the Bronx, New York City authorities said yesterday.

LEAD: FAT CITY Directed by John Huston. With Stacy Keach (in photo), Jeff Bridges and Susan Tyrrell (in photo). RCA/Columbia Home Video. 96 minutes. $69.95.
LEAD: My earliest recollections of a hospital were of St. Mary's, in a town in upstate New York.

LEAD: Tennis Courses Question:Do any Northeastern ski resorts run tennis schools with lodging in the summer? - F. T. S., Princeton, N.J. Answer:Many ski areas in the Northeast have tennis courts, and some - like Waterville Valley, N.H. - will have instructors on duty, but their use for summer courses with rooms included seems to be limited to Vermont.

LEAD: STARLIGHT, by Scott Ely. (Warner, $4.50.) Tom Light, an American sniper in Vietnam, is rumored to have powers over life and death - and a rifle scope that can tell who is about to die. Last year, our reviewer, Richard Burgin, said this novel is written in ''a pared-down prose that controls and accentuates its author's fury at the war.

LEAD: The second round of peace talks between the Sandinista Government and contra guerrilla leaders ended today without an accord. Government officials said a third round would begin May 12, but the contras said they had not agreed to a date.

LEAD: I read the letter from Jane Goldblatt to the Long Island editor on March 6 and was disturbed by her attitude toward educating the handicaped. I would like to offer a rebuttal, strictly addressing her need for defining education. I am a speech therapist working in special education in the public domain and have been for over 20 years.

LEAD: At Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington, Patricia Anne Shean, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Leonard Shean of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to David Paul Kelley 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Philip Kelley of Atlanta. The Rev. Richard F. Smith performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Amy Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sullivan of Valley Stream, L.I., and Thomas E. Pajusi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmo Pajusi of Pelham Manor, N.Y., were married yesterday in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan. The Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Israeli Arabs need only look at the second-class status of Jews in Moslem lands to appreciate the rights and freedoms they enjoy as an increasingly hostile minority in Israel (''Arab Rage Inside Israel,'' by Ze'ev Chafets, April 3). But Israeli Arabs want it both ways: they demand full acceptance as Israeli citizens while proclaiming loyalty to an Arab state on the West Bank whose leaders are sworn to the dismantling of Israel.

LEAD: Its owner was impossible, its architect impractical, its workers often unpaid; it was the wrong building at the wrong time in the wrong climate, a visionary extravagance that affronted many of its visitors and was abandoned within 30 years of its completion. And yet, today, despite restoration work and scaffolding, the Royal Pavilion at Brighton shines forth as the proof that style and imagination can indeed create the most unlikely of masterpieces.
LEAD: The letter by Judith Leventhal, clinical psychologist, and Susan Ueber Raymond, health planner [ March 27 ] , concerns me.
LEAD: ''The best people don't run,'' said Sylke Benner, a marketing manager, ''and they're the smartest people.''

LEAD: Whoa, wait just a darned nanosecond. We've been reading more and more lately about something called zero wait states, usually in the context of computer makers bragging about their machines being better than other computers. Some machines are said to have one wait state. If that's so great, why are some computer makers - like the Tandy Corporation, the Dell Computer Corporation and Zenith Electronics

LEAD: This year's contenders for the Kentucky Derby May 7 have seemed close together in ability all year, but they have never been closer than they were today at the finish of the spring's final prep race.
LEAD: AFTER nearly five months of negotiations and more than halfway through the fiscal year, general hospitals all have approved budgets.

LEAD: For the next three months, a 40-foot-high model of an ancient Egyptian temple will stand at the front of the Boston Museum of Science. The building is the temporary home of the imposing Colossus of Memphis, a 3,000-year-old, 57-ton granite statue of Ramses II.

LEAD: SO Dickensian is the new exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art that its curator, Julian Treuherz, might have left the title at ''Hard Times.'' But Mr. Treuherz, who is keeper of fine arts at the Manchester City Art Gallery (where the show originated) chose ''Hard Times: Victorian Social Realism'' instead.
LEAD: For the second consecutive day, Joe Falcon led the University of Arkansas to a major Penn Relays victory with a dazzling come-from-behind anchor leg.

LEAD: Striking ferry workers pelted busloads of tourists with rocks and bottles today after mistaking them for strikebreakers, the police said. Later, two ferries docked at Dover as the boat company moved to crush the work stoppage.

LEAD: BY even the most conservative estimate, New York City needs 230,000 more places to live. The rate of housing abandonment has slowed in recent years, but construction of new apartments and houses has remained anemic.
LEAD: A SINISTER FORCE for solecism exists on Madison Avenue. It is the work of the copywrongers.

LEAD: As strains of ''Amazing Grace'' streamed down Fifth Avenue yesterday morning, 8,000 police officers saluted the flag-draped coffin of Sgt. John F. McCormick, who was slain last week in a drug raid - a victim, many of his comrades said, in a battle without purpose and a war without end.
LEAD: Until 1948 when the Cold War slammed shut the back doors of the United States and Soviet Union, Alaskan Eskimos crossed the Bering Strait in motorboats to visit relatives in Soviet Siberia.

LEAD: Collectors of the popular Disney stamps issued by client states of New York's Inter-Governmental Philatelic Corporation can look forward to a new set this Tuesday from Antigua and Barbados. The set of eight stamps and two souvenir sheets illustrates Disney characters at various Epcot Center sites.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Susan Jennings Garfield, a loan officer in private banking at the Shawmut Bank in Boston, and Charles Higginson Jr., an oil trader with Catamount Petroleum in Boston, plan to be married May 28.

LEAD: THE Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives gave his application for citizenship a boost last week, but it will take more than citizenship to clear the way for Jens-Peter Berndt to join the United States Olympic swimming team. Under International Olympic Committee rules, Berndt, who has been attending the University of Alabama since defecting from East Germany in 1985, needs a waiver from his native country.

LEAD: RAYMONDA The Bolshoi Ballet, starring Ludmila Semenyaka (in photo), Irek Mukhamedov and Gedeminas Taranda. Choreographed by Yuri Grigorovitch and Marius Petipa. Music by Alexander Glazunov. Kultur. 146 minutes. $39.95.

LEAD: To an expert standing on the operating deck at the heart of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, the plant looks as poised to produce energy as kindling stacked in a fireplace or water impounded behind a dam.

LEAD: Project 39 director Jim Brehm's statement estimating that the yet-to-be-finished steam locomotive and the yet-to-even-be-started railroad museum will ''bring in 150,000 visitors a year'' is, I believe, overly optimistic [ ''Rail Museum to Displace a Furniture Company,'' March 27 ] .

LEAD: One can only imagine the astonishment of 19th-century explorers upon finding under jungle creepers and desert sands carefully worked stone figures and large, complex structures. With ancient texts as their sole guides, they must have fancied that these cities of rock had sprung from the pages of classical literature, rather than the other way around.

LEAD: Elizabeth Perle has been named publisher of Prentice-Hall Press. She was previously associate publisher of hardcover and trade paperbacks at Bantam Books, where she held positions in marketing and sales. Prior to that she was employed at Harper & Row and Times Books. The press is part of the Prentice Hall Trade Division, itself part of Simon & Schuster's consumer group.

LEAD: For years, the standard itinerary to Charleston, S.C., included touring a meticulously restored home, riding the ferry to Fort Sumter, dining on a bowl of she-crab soup and picking up a souvenir: a coiled seagrass basket, or perhaps a miniature bale of cotton.

LEAD: Maggie Tulliver, George Eliot's heroine in ''The Mill on the Floss,'' thought making patchwork was foolish -''tearing things to pieces to sew 'em together again.'' But it would be hard to come away from a tiny shop in Toronto without being impressed by the skill and panache of 19th- and early 20th-century
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Ginway of Lake Forest, Ill., and Mantoloking, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie McDowell Ginway to Peter Craig Gambee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Craig Gambee of Weston, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: The marriage of Karen Beth Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Goldberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., to David Charles Berkey took place last night at the Puck Building in New York. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Frances Berkey of Scarsdale and the late Benjamin Berkey, who founded Berkey Photo.

LEAD: When Motorola Inc. introduced a system of quality control at its plant in Arcade, N.Y., it found that many employees lacked the mathematical skills needed to understand the new statistics-based approach. In response, Motorola officials added six hours of remedial training in grade-school mathematics for all workers.
LEAD: WHEN Johann Strauss wrote his ''Voices of Spring,'' he might well have been describing the bountiful harvest of vocal concerts in Connecticut this week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TULIP TIME With its roots firmly set in Long Island's Dutch past, and don't forget those 70,000 tulips to that dot the campus, Hofstra University holds its annual Dutch Festival today. This time, from noon to 5 P.M., it has a bit more than the customary walking tours of the Hempstead campus.

LEAD: The Afghan soldier on guard in downtown Kabul looked rather smart in his green fatigues, except for one detail. He had carelessly put on his brass belt buckle so that the hammer and sickle were upside down.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S stocking steelhead trout and chinook salmon in the Raritan River has infuriated the Hudson River Fishermen's Association.

LEAD: I smile and nod as I walk by a nurse seated behind the reception desk. When I first started visiting my grandfather's nursing home a couple of years ago, I always stopped to sign the guest book in the lobby. But now I feel visiting anonymously is preferable to advertising my presence.

LEAD: The ideal, to achieve a style perfectly balanced for both attack and defense, is seen very rarely. The games of three world champions, Bobby Fischer, Boris Spassky and Gary Kasparov, are perhaps the best illustrations of the universal man. Most of the other champions have gravitated toward the attacking pole of an Alexander Alekhine or Mikhail Tal or the defensive pole of an Emanuel Lasker or Tigran
LEAD: Jose Canseco hit a three-run homer, and Carney Lansford had three hits as the Oakland Athletics extended their winning streak to six with an 11-3 rout of the Indians today.

LEAD: While some New York City piers continue to receive cargo and many others crumble into the slime, Pier A awaits a restaurant, Pier 84 a permanent concert stage and Pier 10 a floating museum. A wave of development proposals washing over the waterfront also includes plans for ferry terminals, marinas, condominiums and hotels.
LEAD: ALIAS MADAME DOUBTFIRE By Anne Fine. 199 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company.

LEAD: John MacLean (15) and teammates after he scored winning goal for the Devils in the third period last night against the Capitals in Landover, Md. The Devils now meet Boston in the Stanley Cup semifinals. Section 8. (AP)

LEAD: INTIMATE STRANGERS: New Stories From Quebec. Edited by Matt Cohen and Wayne Grady. (Penguin, Paper, $6.95.) Canadian literature remains, in this country, largely an unknown landscape, one in which only a few figures have much visibility. And so the large, robust and diverse body of work produced by the generation of French Canadian writers who came of age in the 1970's has been virtually invisible in the United States.

LEAD: MOTORISTS using the eastern spur of the New Jersey Turnpike between Newark and the Lincoln Tunnel exit are feeling the impact of construction on the western spur, which carries traffic between Newark and the George Washington Bridge exit.

LEAD: MY 9-year-old loves baseball. He can't go into a drugstore without wanting to buy trading cards. He's a Yankees fan who knows the statistics of every player on the team, and whenever we're sitting at the table, or car pooling, he explains the subtleties of the game to me. He never tires of its intricacies, and sometimes

LEAD: CINNAMON TEALS, according to the staff of this new Danbury restaurant, is named for a duck. It is also in a shopping complex called Cinnamon Plaza. To emphasize the theme, duck decoys decorate one wall, and the menu is graced with duck drawings.

LEAD: A key tip-in by Dennis Johnson. A blocked shot by Kevin McHale. A foul by Kenny Walker and two free throws by Larry Bird. A few Knick turnovers, some missed shots and a tighter Boston Celtic defense.

LEAD: ''Maple taffy on the snow (no limit), boiled potatoes, home-fried potatoes, grilled salted pork, eggs sunnyside up, omelets, homemade bread, maple dumplings (in syrup), eggs in syrup, homemade ketchup and pickles,'' read the menu.

LEAD: The article ''New Product Is Offered to Reduce Lyme Disease'' [ April 3 ] did an excellent job in reporting information as presented by the manufacturer of Damminix, by authorities in the field of Lyme disease, by health officials, etc. Some additional caveats are in order.
LEAD: A LONG line of farmers and gardeners make up my family tree, but when genes for a green thumb were handed out, I was not on the list.

LEAD: The director of the District of Columbia's Department of Human Services and three aides have resigned after reports surfaced that the three used city funds to pay their rent and food bills, officials said today.

LEAD: Ze'ev Chafets reports that in Israel there are ''more than 50 organizations dedicated to Arab-Jewish understanding.'' Query: How many such organizations are there among Israeli Arabs in the West Bank or anywhere in the Arab world? The answer is: None. That fact is only one reason why the possibility of reconciliation and peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors is, perhaps, even more remote than Mr.

LEAD: Q. I recently painted my living room. The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places. It has been painted many times before. How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

LEAD: One year after the first disclosures of possible bribery in an arms contract, the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi remains beset by corruption charges and a deepening mystery about who received a series of illegal payments from abroad.

LEAD: To the Editor: Though I enjoyed Cynthia Samuels' article on traveling with children (Travel, Jan. 24), I wish to correct two pieces of information regarding air travel that appeared in the accompanying box by Dennis Hevesi. My information is based on a trip we took to Rome last summer with our 6-month-old daughter and on several domestic trips.

LEAD: A report in the Travel Advisory on Feb. 28 misstated the days on which the Emily Dickinson Homestead in Amherst, Mass., is open for tours from May through October. They are Wednesday to Saturday, in the afternoon.

LEAD: After nearly two decades of bearing witness to suits, countersuits and endless appeals, Ethel Lawrence, a 62-year-old grandmother from Mount Laurel, N.J., recites without pause the gist of complex rulings handed down by the New Jersey Supreme Court and cited in discriminatory zoning cases across the nation.

LEAD: In a resounding rejection of Reagan Administration policy, a Federal district judge here ruled late Friday that the Government had coerced Salvadorans seeking asylum into leaving the country, and must stop the practice.

LEAD: The craft of letter writ-ing is in a low, flickering state, historians of the form admit, kept alive only by irate people who carry on endless, fruitless correspondence with utility company computers. It was different in earlier times, when there was no telephone, or if there was one it had to be cranked each time.
LEAD: John MacLean again proved to be the biggest hero of the spring for the Devils as he scored the winning goal tonight to put the Devils into the Stanley Cup semifinals.

LEAD: Julia Anne Thomas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Thomas of Exeter, N.H., and Marc V. Johnson, a son of Anne F. Ryan and C. R. Johnson Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn.

LEAD: To the Editor: Switzerland has instituted an entrance fee to use its highways. They charge 40 Swiss francs (about $24) to enter the country driving a car. What is unfair is that this charge is a yearly one, so that anyone who drives into Switzerland for a visit of a couple of hours, as we did, is required to pay the fee.

LEAD: Patricia Perkins Ogden and John William McGrath were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley. The bride, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Donald Perkins, is the manager of membership and major gifts at the New York Zoological Society.

LEAD: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, what is now known as the Route 9 corridor through western Monmouth County was a scenic two-lane back road dotted with truck farms and, in season, roadside stands selling fresh produce.

LEAD: In 1980, a scuffle in the gymnasium of New Dorp High School on Staten Island erupted into violence. Black students were forced to flee in buses as white students hurled stones and shouted racial epithets. The school was closed temporarily, and it was days before black students returned to class.

LEAD: The scenario depicted in Penny Singer's article [ ''Diabetic Doctor Offers a New Treatment,'' April 3 ] is the stuff of old Hollywood romances: lone figure with miraculous intuitive insight struggles valiantly against his own affliction as well as against an indifferent, reactionary medical establishment unwilling to take at face value his anecdotal account of self-salvation and restoration to health.

LEAD: Dancers stepped into new roles at performances of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Sleeping Beauty,'' presented by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday. The standard of dancing by the leads was high, with Amanda McKerrow and Wes Chapman dancing Princess Aurora and Prince Desire in the afternoon and Cheryl Yeager and Julio Bocca dancing the roles in the evening.

LEAD: I WAS alone in my kitchen one recent Sunday morning, reading an interview in the Long Island Weekly with David Emilita [ ''A Planner Balances Quantity and Quality'' ] . Upon reading his words about affordable housing, I wanted to stand up and applaud.

LEAD: An appearance by the pianist Claudio Arrau, planned for May 18 at the 92d Street Y, has been canceled due to illness. The concert, which has not been rescheduled, was the last in this season's Distinguished Artists Series at the Y. Refunds are available by mail from the 92d Street Y box office, 1395 Lexington Avenue.

LEAD: When the audience first meets Pale, the central figure in Lanford Wilson's ''Burn This,'' he is offstage, pounding on a stranger's apartment door, screaming obscenities at an unseen antagonist. It is well past midnight and Anna, the female character in Mr. Wilson's play at the Plymouth, looks confused and bleary-eyed switching on a light and peering through the peephole.

LEAD: For years, architects and designers in major cities have been restoring and renovating buildings that date from early in this century. Evident from the street are highly polished stone facades, or those freshly painted in colors reproduced from original paint chips. And inside many residential buildings, apartments are also being renovated in ways that make them appear as though they had never been prey to decades of changing tastes.

LEAD: Thousands of starving refugees from the Sudan, fleeing drought and civil war in their country's south, are crossing the border into southwestern Ethiopia every month and severely taxing overcrowded relief camps.

LEAD: To the Editor: I read with interest the article on courier services (Travel, March 6) as I have flown to Europe the past two years that way - the first time with TNT Skypak and the second arranged by Now Voyager.
LEAD: Valerie Holmes

LEAD: TWO fine young Westchester pianists, and another who is already a world-renowned artist, are enhancing the recital scene this week. William Wolfram returns to his alma mater today, Cynthia Peterson presents an unusual fusion of music and spirituality on Saturday and Garrick Ohlsson, also on Saturday, closes out the season for Friends of
LEAD: To the Editor:

Schlitz of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and the late Ann Schaffner Schlitz, was married yesterday to Worth Daniels MacMurray, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank G. MacMurray of McLean and Madison, Va. Canon Charles Martin performed the Episcopal ceremony in the great choir at the Washington

LEAD: No careening chandeliers, no raving madman scurrying across a false proscenium. No roller skates, no barricade, no neon dragons descending from the heights. Just two couples in two small musical plays about grown-up love in ''Romance, Romance.''
LEAD: There are now two fewer friends for the homeless on Long Island. Their departure leaves a gaping hole in the distribution of children's clothing to the needy.

LEAD: Back in the days when the notion of a Baltimore Orioles victory was nothing more than fantasy - why, it seems like only yesterday - everyone up to and including the manager wondered about the climactic moment.

LEAD: One year after New York City launched a drive to tame the wide-open nonmedallion taxi industry by giving the Taxi and Limousine Commission jurisdiction over the cars and drivers in that business, the result has justified neither the worst fears of the car services nor the best hopes of city officials.

LEAD: TRADE groups have always been concerned with lobbying. But today, ''the number of associations that don't have an active government relations program is so minuscule as to be almost uncountable,'' said Michael D. Lane, executive director of the Associations Council of the National Association of Manufacturers.

LEAD: The United States Olympic Committee's annual House of Delegates meeting ended today with no major decisions. However, one minor decision seemed to reflect a growing feeling among some members that less money should be spent on direct aid to athletes and programs of other countries.

LEAD: The League of Women Voters of Westchester believes it is imperative to solve the crisis of homeless people in our midst - so often discussed in this section. A first step is being offered by HELP II. We support immediate action to adopt the proposed HELP II projects.

LEAD: Mary-Suzanne Peterson, a securities analyst at the First Boston Corporation in New York, and Robert A. Case, a principal in mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

LEAD: The new laboratory and classroom facility at the Oregon Institute of Technology in Klamath Falls was designed by Michael R. McCulloch ''to make a transition,'' he says, ''between the inside of campus and the outside, where there's a dramatic backdrop of mountains.'' So its 1,800-square-foot, crescent-shaped skylight, created by the Portland artist Ed Carpenter, is integral to the building's architectural intent.

LEAD: Q. I recently painted my living room. The radiator, which is the old-fashioned cast-iron type, has brown stains on it and is peeling in places. It has been painted many times before. How can I paint this so it won't develop these dark stains and peel, and can I do this while the heat is on?

LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on March 27 about lost and stolen airline tickets carried an incorrect report from Northwest Airlines about its policy. The service charge for refunding a ticket is $50 for a domestic ticket and $30 for an international ticket.
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange will know within a few days whether an unusual test of its computer systems was a success, according to officials for the Big Board.

LEAD: Tommy Aaron, the 1973 Masters champion, produced a legendary shot today when he holed out from 115 yards at the par-4 16th hole on the Onion Creek Club for an eagle that led to a playoff in the 11th annual Liberty Mutual Legends of Golf.
LEAD: An upcoming report by Surgeon General C. Everett Koop will declare that nicotine is an addictive drug, the head of the Federal Office of Smoking and Health said today.

LEAD: ANYONE who is serious about fitness must eventually confront the fat, or lipids, in his or her blood. An ambitious weekly exercise effort aimed at a healthy heart can provide a false sense of overall fitness if blood lipids are out of kilter.

LEAD: The chief of staff to a Maryland Congressman died yesterday when he plunged from a 24th-floor window of the Helmsley Palace hotel in Manhattan, the police said. They said it was apparently a suicide.

LEAD: ''Mental real estate'' is how Jeffery B. Baer, a Denver investor and entrepreneur, described the reason for his family's acquisition of the Famous Amos Chocolate Chip Cookie Corporation ''It needs to be developed,'' Mr. Baer, Amos's new chairman, said after the Friday announcement. ''It's not a piece of ground, but the principle is the same.
LEAD: General Assembly DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: A man with a history of mental illness, who apparently went berserk and clubbed a woman to death with a two-by-four in Harlem Saturday, collapsed in a crowded cell at Police Headquarters yesterday and died soon afterward.
LEAD: Japan's agriculture minister will remain in Washington in an effort to break the deadlock in negotiations over barriers against the sale of more United States beef and oranges in Japan.

LEAD: Red Flag, the theoretical journal of China's Communist Party for three decades and long a stronghold of hard-line Marxists, will shut down this summer, the official New China News Agency reported today.
LEAD: ONE recent Saturday night, Connie Chung, the anchor of the weekend version of ''NBC Nightly News,'' was reading an urgent story about the Middle East, when she began to disappear.

LEAD: SPONSORS of limited real estate partnerships are like badly wounded soldiers. Having been dealt a blow by the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and by further tax changes last year, the sponsors are ever so slowly recovering.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Dr. Diane Amy Benezra, a daughter of Edith Benezra of Lauderhill, Fla., and the late Max Benezra, was married yesterday to Peter Jay Kurshan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Kurshan of Woodmere, L.I., and New York. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion officiated.
LEAD: Each Afghan refugee bears the reactions and disturbed mental life of war and exile, an Afghan psychiatrist says.
LEAD: A Blaze of Glory
LEAD: Phil Parsons won the first Nascar race of his career today, holding off Bobby Allison and Geoff Bodine to win the Winston 500 at Alabama International Motor Speedway.
LEAD: The National Academy of Sciences, often described as the nation's most prestigious honorary society for scientists, has announced the election of 61 new members.

LEAD: Robin Hally Winter, a daughter of Mrs. Howard Norton Blitman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., and Dr. Leo Winter Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Erik Ferens Tinkhauser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Emerich Rudolf Tinkhauser of Freeport, L.I., and Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New
LEAD: Ben Lexcen, who designed the yacht that ended the 132-year reign of the United States in America's Cup racing, died Sunday night. He was 52 years old.

LEAD: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the ultra-right National Front, called on his supporters today not to vote for President Francois Mitterrand on May 8, but he declined to endorse the Socialist head of state's conservative challenger, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac.

LEAD: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed unexpectedly and sharply in March to a seasonally adjusted $1.61 billion from $2.48 billion in February, the Government said Friday. Nevertheless, the deficit was much wider than the deficit a year ago, which came to $703 million. Britain's total trade deficit also narrowed sharply.

LEAD: A group of key Senators has rejected President Reagan's proposal for government leasing of much of a no-frills space station that would be commercially developed and owned. The Senators instead ordered an independent assessment of the proposed station's merits.

LEAD: With remarkable speed, yesterday's terrorists turn into today's statesmen. Consider the Middle East rebellion by a stateless people against an occupying army whose soldiers were special targets in a campaign to seize world attention.

LEAD: Volkswagen United States said it would raise the prices of its Fox models by an average of 5 percent, or $359 a vehicle, effective Monday. The company attributed the increase to economic pressures in Brazil, where the car is manufactured.

LEAD: With five months remaining before the 1988 World Team Olympiad, scheduled in Venice in October, national organizations are making the moves needed to select their teams. The United States teams will be determined by playoff matches scheduled in Memphis in June.

LEAD: WITH his racquet bag slung over his shoulder, John McEnroe was in no particular hurry as he walked from the practice court to the locker room at the Horseshoe Bend Country Club in suburban Atlanta last week, pleasant surroundings on what he hopes is the road back to the top of the tennis rankings.

LEAD: With Nicaragua facing its first major labor conflict since the 1979 revolution, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra denounced opposition labor organizers today as ''pseudo-leaders who receive money from the C.I.A.''

LEAD: Michael Jordan scored 55 points to become the first player to score 50 or more in two consecutive National Basketball Association playoff games as Chicago beat Cleveland, 106-101, today. The Bulls took a 2-games-to-0 lead in their Eastern Conference series.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Most Arabs holding jobs in Israel have showed up for work regularly, except for the most violent weeks of the Palestinian uprising, according to the Government. That frustrates the uprising's leadership. Page A1
LEAD: International Report

LEAD: With four miles to go, she knew the race was hers. With 100 yards to go, she looked more like a sprinter. Crossing the finish line in the fastest time by an American woman in almost three years, Margaret Groos looked fresh enough to head straight for the victory party.
LEAD: When Vice President Bush visited Ohio State University, he picked up one legendary Buckeye's endorsement from beyond the grave.

LEAD: When the Canadian Government announced last month that it would offer 45 percent of the equity in Air Canada, the state-owned airline, to the public, it stirred a political furor. In the House of Commons, Edward Broadbent, a leading opposition figure with the New Democratic Party, denounced the move as ''a triumph of Conservative ideology over good, common Canadian sense.
LEAD: IT is the stuff of fantasies, something that Jerome James might daydream about while cruising the streets of Sioux Falls, S.D., in his police car.

LEAD: In a move that could affect musicians around the country, members of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra have voted to leave the American Federation of Musicians and join a new union for representation in contract talks this year.

LEAD: Better known for defending Black Panthers, Hell's Angels and members of the Symbionese Liberation Army, J. Tony Serra has lately directed his anti-establishment advocacy toward protecting a skateboard ramp that his sons built and the neighbors want torn down.

LEAD: Information Resources of Chicago, the nation's third-largest marketing research company, is making an interesting diversification move: into TV-equipped supermarket carts. It is called ''VideOcart,'' with a capital O. That's right, carts that have 6-by-8-inch video screens mounted on the handles and cued electronically to run commercials when they pass the shelfspace of an advertiser's products.
LEAD: The Christian Broadcasting Network has canceled two shows produced by the Jimmy Swaggart ministry because Mr. Swaggart refused to stop appearing on them, a spokesman said today.

LEAD: THE goal came from nowhere, a looping shot, more or less chipped into the air, rising over a diving player, obscured by two grappling players, then fluttering over the right shoulder of Sean Burke, the goalie of the New Jersey Devils.
LEAD: There is a rush on to acquire sales promotion companies, and it must be a reflection of the fact that larger slices of the marketing pie are being diverted to that discipline.

LEAD: John S. Chamberlin, who resigned last week as president and chief operating officer in an unexpected development at Avon Products Inc., said yesterday that the move was mostly the result of changes in Avon's business since he took his post three years ago.

LEAD: One hundred children from Jacques d'Amboise's National Dance Institute will perform in ''Dancing the New Stories'' on May 10 at Alice Tully Hall. The event, directed by Mr. d'Amboise and presented by the institute and Lincoln Center's Meet-the-Artist program, will include a tribute to Irving Berlin, based on his song ''God Bless America,'' on the eve of his 100th birthday.
LEAD: THE pleasures of hunting wild turkeys are certainly not confined to shooting these wonderful birds.
LEAD: QUESTION: Why is the American League sometimes referred to as the junior circuit?

LEAD: The plethora of new trade publications, self-improvement books and special-interest consumer magazines and newspaper sections is testimony to a change in America's reading habits. Now a number of studies are documenting just how much those habits have changed.
LEAD: Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, the peerless first couple of the American theater, were honored by the American Academy of Dramatic Arts last night at a gala tribute at the St. Regis Hotel.

LEAD: TERRY O'REILLY, the Bruins' bully-turned-coach, actually cringed his way through the series with Montreal that earned Boston the privilege of facing the Devils in the Prince of Wales Conference championship series, which begins tonight.

LEAD: HOW strange it is that an adver= tiser with a budget of only $1 million for television should be planning to use 60-second spots instead of something shorter to make the money go further - get more messages for the buck.

LEAD: Only a few years after vowing never again to throw big bucks after big books, the publishing industry is spending huge sums in pursuit of authors. And while the risks are as enormous as they used to be, the way the big money is spent today is significantly different.

LEAD: Mary Alice Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Agnew Fisher of Greenwich, Conn., and David Kinne Carmichael, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank K. Carmichael of Northford, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside,
LEAD: Coach Rick Pitino stood in a hall at the Boston Garden, sifting through the ashes of the Knicks' second playoff loss. Nearby, Coach K. C. Jones was explaining how his Celtics had set the fire.

LEAD: The first California condor conceived in captivity ate a hearty diet of chopped mice today as keepers kept a close eye on the chick that boosted the number of the endangered birds to 28. ''The appetite of the bird is very good,'' said Martha Baker, spokeswoman for the San Diego Wild Animal Park, where the chick was hatched with human help on Friday.

LEAD: Samuel M. Ehrenhalt has an odd passion for statistics. Nothing sets him to dancing like a good strong quarterly report in employment. A steep trend line in new-business formations makes him break into song.
LEAD: China is fast developing into one of the world's leading exporters, chiefly to finance its growing demand for food imports, the Central Intelligence Agency reported today.

LEAD: At Temple Beth Am in Merrick, L.I., Rona Silver, the daughter of Jean Silver of Merrick and the late Stanley W. Silver, was married yesterday to Dr. Kevin Loshak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Loshak, also of Merrick. Rabbi Ronald N. Brown officiated. Mrs. Loshak, a sales marketing planner in advertising at The New York Times, graduated from the State University at Albany, as did her husband.
LEAD: New York State is moving to set up a program that gives thousands of poor, single mothers guaranteed child-support payments and new incentives to get off the welfare rolls.

LEAD: Three hours before the game, Dave Pallone's official blue blazer hung on the door of the umpires' dressing room in the basement of Riverfront Stadium. It was wrapped in a local dry cleaner's plastic and was stapled with a receipt showing the Reds had picked up the bill for $3.

LEAD: Forty Niner erased any doubts about his fitness for the Kentucky Derby Saturday with a fine one-mile workout this morning, and his trainer then predicted that the colt would help keep the filly Winning Colors from winning the race.
LEAD: Freaky Deaky By Elmore Leonard 341 pages. Arbor House/William Morrow. $18.95.

LEAD: Laura Beatrice Kavesh, a columnist for The Chicago Tribune, and Dr. Steven Stern, an assistant professor of psychiatry and psychology at the Northwestern University Medical School, were married yesterday in Chicago. Rabbi Michael Siegel performed the ceremony at the Anshe Emet Synagogue.
LEAD: Antonio Garcia Gonzalez has spent most of the past year shining shoes, selling Mexican newspapers and candies and smiling a nearly toothless smile outside the legalization office.
LEAD: I am writing this with an old-fashioned, user-hostile pen while riding, if that verb can be used, in a New York City taxicab.

LEAD: Robbery, which some experts say is the best indicator of how safe a city is, has dropped 26 percent in New York City since 1981, and the police attribute the drop to new anti-robbery teams, computer tracking of robbery patterns and other recent innovations.

LEAD: Tod Seisser and Jay Taub, one of three creative-director teams at Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, have left the agency to help a Los Angeles agency try the difficult job of gaining a foothold in New York.

LEAD: WOULD you drive off on a cross-country trip this spring or summer without getting your car tuned up first? Probably not. And you shouldn't embark on an active schedule of outdoor tennis without getting your racquet tuned up.

LEAD: There is a little-known but powerful section of the Justice Department, the Office of Legal Counsel, that serves as the executive branch's brain trust on the most fundamental issues of Presidential power.

LEAD: One person was killed and four others were injured yesterday when a sightseeing helicopter crashed into the cold East River minutes before it was to land at the 34th Street heliport in Manhattan.

LEAD: About 500 people clashed with the police in the northern city of Gdansk today, and official May Day parades in several other Polish cities were countered by demonstrators bearing banners of the banned Solidarity trade union.
LEAD: PROSPECTS for changes in takeover and insider trading laws are rapidly diminishing on Capitol Hill, according to some legislators, regulators and lobbyists.

LEAD: In the latest round in its battle to gain control of the USG Corporation, Desert Partners L.P. said yesterday that it would pay $45 a share in cash for 39 million outstanding shares if a friendly deal could be worked out.

LEAD: Eight months before a general election that will probably include some of the most costly Senate contests ever waged, the 27 incumbents facing re-election had amassed $63 million to finance their campaigns.

LEAD: Rick Pitino threw the coaching book at the Boston Celtics today. The Knicks trapped and they pressed. They tried a small lineup and a big lineup. They played Patrick Ewing and Bill Cartwright, their 7-foot centers, with three guards.
LEAD: The economy expanded at a faster rate in April after three months of slow growth, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report scheduled to be released today.

LEAD: Pacy Markham says that someday he will write his memoirs of two decades in the advertising business, and the chapter devoted to his trauma and torment will be entitled, ''Sentenced to the Gallos.''

Brancato of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Louis Potters, a son of Mrs. Milton Potters of South Orange, N.J., and the late Dr. Potters. The Rev. Stanley Moseley, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony.

LEAD: When Ronald Reagan took office, his advisers called for the smack of strong measures in Central America. This President wanted results, they said, not human rights reports or Panama Canal treaties. Results meant getting rid of the Sandinistas in Nicaragua and crushing guerrilla forces in El Salvador's civil war.

LEAD: Spurred by the declining value of the dollar, a resulting pickup in exports and a rapid upgrading of its factories, the industrial establishment of the Midwest has begun almost overnight to catch up with the the rest of the country's economic recovery.

LEAD: Expectations of Cuba attending the Seoul Olympics are changing again, in fact, this time they are diminishing.

LEAD: Growing numbers of poor, young teen-agers are abusing crack in New York City, but there is practically no place for parents or social-service agencies to send them for drug treatment, according to experts in drug abuse and youth issues.

LEAD: Stan Javier drove in two runs with a bases-loaded single, and Mark McGwire doubled in two more runs during a six-run ninth inning today as Oakland rallied to beat the Cleveland Indians, 8-4, for the Athletics' seventh straight victory.

LEAD: The Supreme Court was once remote and mysterious, the Federal equivalent of Mount Olympus. It may even be argued that the remoteness was a source of power: Olympus could command in a way that politicians could not. A Justice had a divine calling. Divinity, however, is hard to sustain in a media age.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts today assailed Vice President Bush for campaigning as if his opponent were Jimmy Carter and said Mr. Bush's record was ''a blank slate'' and therefore hard to judge.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE ultimate for the Devils this season was to make the playoffs. Then the ultimate became being the Patrick Division champions. Now, the ultimate goal is to have their names engraved on hockey's most coveted prize.

LEAD: A classic boot-foot wader made of rubber is all that most fly fishermen need to complement the cache of tackle they take with them to the river. But for the sportsman who wants comfort and warmth, there's the boot-foot wader with a neoprene top.

LEAD: For the last 15 years, Representative William D. Ford, whose constituents are blue-collar and white-collar auto and steel workers in the western suburbs of Detroit, has been trying to legislate prior notice of factory shutdowns or layoffs.

LEAD: About 300 people marched on the Indiana University campus tonight, demanding that Bob Knight, the school's basketball coach, apologize publicly for his televised statement on rape and stress. The protesters also called on administrators to reprimand Knight and to make rape-awareness workshops mandatory for athletic teams.
LEAD: The Bank of New York announced yesterday that it had extended its tender offer for the Irving Bank Corporation until Friday, when a proxy fight is expected at Irving's annual meeting.
LEAD: Reports to the Federal Election Commission tell how much money each candidate has raised. Chart showing 33 contests, page B8.

LEAD: Bustling from cult marginality into the mainstream, the original-instruments movement has attracted greater attention than any other recent trend in the performance of classical music. And no part of the United States has a more active, intensely interconnected early-music community than the San Francisco Bay Area.
LEAD: A bus filled with shoppers was blown apart today and at least 26 passengers were killed when Tamil rebels detonated explosives that had been buried in the ground, military officials said.

LEAD: George E. Mylonas, an internationally recognized authority on Greek archeology and a longtime teacher at Washington University in St. Louis, died April 15 after suffering a heart attack in Athens, where he lived. He was 89 years old.
LEAD: For those wondering about his intentions at the Democratic National Convention, the Rev. Jesse Jackson offered this today:
LEAD: Professors from America's leading business schools may soon be teaching Western business practices to top civil servants and managers in the Soviet Union.
