LEAD: ''Romance Romance,'' lately the littlest big musical Off Off Broadway, has made it uptown, in a slightly enhanced production that loses nothing of the charm and intelligence of the original and gains a thoroughly winning performance by Alison Fraser.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed by an auction of one-year bills on Thursday. On Wednesday the Treasury is expected to announce the size of next week's quarterly refunding. Most analysts expect the Treasury will sell between $26 billion and $27 billion of 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.

LEAD: * American Medical Buildings Inc., Milwaukee, a builder and designer of health-care facilities, named Michael A. Carlson president and chief executive to replace John Lundeen, who has resigned but who will continue in an executive capacity for new-business development.
LEAD: Vietnamese refugees sailing for Malaysia say they are being brutalized and robbed by Thai fishermen roaming the Gulf of Thailand and the South China Sea.

LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about assistant chefs misstated the background of a chef at Montrachet in Manhattan and misspelled his name. The chef, Brian Whitmer, became the head chef at Montrachet without first serving as sous-chef there.
LEAD: Almost 800 homeless families in New Jersey are facing eviction from the motels where they have been living as the state moves to enforce a limit on emergency housing.

LEAD: West Germany's five leading economic research institutes have raised their forecast for the country's growth this year, in line with Government predictions, but they foresee a slowdown in 1989 because of sagging domestic demand.

LEAD: John Tudor, making his second start of the season, pitched six hitless innings today before he was removed for a pinch-hitter, and the St. Louis Cardinals had 15 hits en route to a 9-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

LEAD: Max Feldberg, a founder of the Zayre Corporation, a large national retail company, died of heart failure last Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 90 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.
LEAD: Standing in the special visitors gallery last Wednesday as Prime Minister Brian Mulroney arrived on the south lawn of the White House was the comedian Red Skelton.

LEAD: When the two Nobel laureates lost their aura a decade ago and the throngs of peace marchers drifted away from the ghettos, there was no shortage of critics to gloat over the failure of ''the fur coat brigade.''

LEAD: Last summer, Tiffany was singing 20-minute sets at shopping malls with her backup on tape. Now, after four hit singles have helped sell four million copies of her debut album, ''Tiffany,'' the 16-year-old singer is fronting a band on her first full-fledged concert tour, which came to the Westbury Music Fair tonight.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration has told Congress that it wants to increase arms sales abroad substantially this year to more than $15 billion worth of weapons. This is $3.3 billion more than the United States sold to other countries last year.

LEAD: Most mornings, Zhame Daragma, a Palestinian from the West Bank town of Tubas, climbs into his car and drives north into Israel where he shows up on time for work in this quiet Jewish village.
LEAD: The deputy commander of an Israeli Army unit was suspended today after one of his men shot and killed a Palestinian in the West Bank village of Faqua, the army said.

LEAD: Grey Advertising released its first-quarter earnings on Friday, and they were good enough to elicit a cautionary note from Edward H. Meyer, its chairman, who said that while he appreciated the performance, he doesn't want shareholders to expect similar percent gains during the rest of the year.

LEAD: ''This is my last chance. I know if I don't at least try, I could be sent back to El Salvador, and that is worse.'' - Maria Sanchez of Houston on the alien amnesty program that ends Wednesday. [ A16:4. ]

LEAD: Tennis Lendl Overcomes Edberg: Ivan Lendl came back from a shaky start to defeat Stefan Edberg yesterday in the final of the $500,000 Challenge in Atlanta. Edberg won the first set, 6-2, but Lendl took the next two sets, 6-1, 6-3, to win the exhibition tournament, held at Horseshoe Bend Country Club.

LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day on April 22 incorrectly characterized the plans of Burt Sugarman's lawyer, Edward Brodsky. Mr. Brodksy said he would appear in Federal court in Richmond contesting a move by Media General Inc. to have Mr. Sugarman's lawsuit dismissed.
LEAD: Eduardo Galeano, a novelist from Uruguay who has completed a subjective, fragmentary and unconventional three-volume history of the Americas, has what might be called a tragic sense of life.

LEAD: Americans treasure the right to speak freely -for everyone except foreigners whose views the Government considers offensive. That's because of the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act of 1952, a vestige of the McCarthy era that blights the nation's willingness to be a marketplace of ideas. Congressional efforts to overhaul this objectionable law at last should get a lift from a recent ruling by a United States Court of Appeals.

LEAD: Coach Joe Walton and most of the Jets' veterans will be reunited tomorrow for the first time since their season ended in bitterness and name-calling.
LEAD: SIX months ago at Hollywood Park, D. Wayne Lukas played five aces and still kept a trump up his sleeve.

LEAD: Participants in the 12th annual Citibank/American Youth Hostel Five Boro Bike Tour on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive yesterday. Riders included unicyclists, recumbent bicyclists, cycling families, Olympic riders, children, cycling pros and riders out for fun, more than 22,000 in all. Of the $6 registration fee for participants in the bike tour, $2 will go toward the development of a 477-bed hostel.
LEAD: In Texas, the land of longhorns and mustangs, the talk is all of lions.

LEAD: The Light Opera of Manhattan, which presents a year-round operetta season, has weathered hard times in recent years. In 1986, after the death of its founder and the loss of its theater, the company suspended operations under the weight of a hefty deficit. But a new board put LOOM's finances straight, and last June the company was reborn.

LEAD: More than two-thirds of the outstanding common shares of the Koppers Company are owned by or have been tendered to the investment group that made a $1.7 billion hostile takeover bid for the company, the group said.
LEAD: Herb Schmertz voted to move the Mobil Corporation's headquarters from Manhattan to suburban Washington. Now he'd like to shift the nation's capital away from Washington.

LEAD: * West Germany's eight bourses reported that trading volume fell in April by nearly 28 percent, to 163.7 billion marks, or $95.4 billion, from 226.5 billion marks, or $135 billion, in March. There were only 19 trading days in April, compared with 23 in March. Also, average daily stock sales in April fell to 8.6 billion marks, or $5.1 billion, from 9.8 billion marks, or $5.8 billion, in March.

LEAD: Pentagon officials in charge of developing the space-based defense system terminated the funds for an advisory panel of computer experts just as a Senate subcommittee was about to make public the findings of an investigation into possible improprieties involving panel members and multimillion-dollar research contracts.

LEAD: It is going on 11 years since the brother of President Jimmy Carter entered the suds business. Billy Beer caused something of a sensation when it was introduced, but 12 months later, in October 1978, Reynolds Metals bought nearly 9 million empty Billy cans and melted them, signaling the end for the brew.

LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended four days of meetings early today without an agreement on a production cut. OPEC officials said the cartel would meet again next month. The failure here is bound to depress oil prices by at least $1 a barrel, an analyst said, because the oil markets had been anticipating some kind of decision to reduce output, which would have propped up oil prices.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner's three-way deal involving Dave Winfield, which would send the Yankee outfielder to Toronto and bring Kevin Bass to New York, may have struck an unforeseen obstacle: Lou Piniella.

LEAD: If, in a trump contract, a declarer plays toward a K-Q combination in the dummy, many defenders step up with the ace because the declarer might have a singleton. They have it backward. Playing low may indeed mean that the ace does not score, but it holds the declarer to one trick in the suit.

LEAD: For the first time in the memory of its top executives, the 61-year-old Hill & Knowlton, a worldwide public relations concern, went outside the company to fill a top executive post.

LEAD: The LTV Corporation today outlined a broad proposal for ending its bankruptcy, the second largest in the nation's history, but its insistence that more than $2 billion in pension liabilities be terminated was immediately challenged by the Government agency that insures corporate pensions.

LEAD: In the broadest statement in months of his views on the economy, Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, said that major countries do not know the optimum exchange rate of the dollar and that unemployment could fall further without causing higher inflation and inducing the Fed to raise interest rates.
LEAD: About two dozen opposition leaders were detained today as they sought to visit a union hall where construction workers are conducting a hunger strike.

LEAD: Pepsico Inc., which says that Pepsi-Cola was the first Western consumer product offered in the Soviet Union (in 1974), now claims to be the first American company to have bought commercial time on Soviet television.
LEAD: The visa allowing the Soviet basketball star Arvidas Sabonis to remain in the United States has been extended for two months, the Portland Trail Blazers announced yesterday.

LEAD: IT seems that most of the men in my life have wanted to possess things, but not actually to purchase them. You see the problem. If I am hanging around the house and it crosses my mind that, hey, we could use a toaster oven, the next logical step in my mental progression is to go to a store where I will buy a toaster oven, tote it home and toast up a storm.

LEAD: New York City officials stunned Chase Manhattan Bank, Citibank and Chemical Bank yesterday by announcing that the three banks would no longer belong to the elite group of managing underwriters for the more than $1 billion of bonds the city sells each year.
LEAD: The Federal Government today began a three-week campaign to inform Americans about AIDS, focused around a pamphlet to be mailed to every household in the nation.

LEAD: At Town Hall Monday night, the Aeolian Chamber Players introduced a brief new work by Peter Lieberson, entitled (without benefit of program-note elucidation) ''Raising the Gaze.'' LEAD: AS the interest in preserving and renovating Art Deco buildings has grown in recent years, home furnishings companies are producing products that recall the patterns and colors of the 1930's. LEAD: A Federal district judge in White Plains scheduled a preliminary hearing for June 3 in the suit filed by Texaco Inc. against Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder. Texaco's annual meeting is on June 7, and Mr. Icahn is seeking to be elected as a director, along with three associates. Texaco wants the court to block him from voting his 14.8 percent share in the company or proxies for others and from buying more shares.

LEAD: The robust good looks of Shohei Imamura's 1968 Cinemascope epic ''The Profound Desire of the Gods'' only heighten the perverse quality of the action, and Mr. Imamura's ribald, casually comic direction has much the same effect. This three-hour film, which will begin the Film Forum 2's Imamura retrospective, makes an ideal introduction to the maverick qualities of this film maker's idiosyncratic style.

LEAD: IT is becoming harder and harder to distinguish good news from bad news. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said this week that he was ''optimistic that the balance of trade will continue to improve in 1988 and beyond.'' That sounded great. But Mr. Greenspan quickly added that the faster the trade balance improves, ''the greater the burden on monetary policy to curtail private domestic spending,'' lest the rapidly improving trade balance, combined with strong domestic spending, accelerate inflation.

LEAD: A newspaper carrier who was injured in a car accident while on the job can file a worker's compensation claim against his newspaper, a state appeals court ruled today The decision by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court allows James Pittman to continue his claim against The Poughkeepsie Journal, a unit of the Gannett Company.

LEAD: Like the bee to the buttercup, like the sledgehammer to the nail, Ken Russell was bound to get around to Oscar Wilde, not the Wilde of ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' or even of ''The Picture of Dorian Gray,'' but the Wilde of the sulphurous, rhapsodic, simile-stuffed ''Salome.'' This is the one-act play Wilde wrote in 1891 in French, the only language he thought pure enough for his vision of the primal encounter between John the Baptist and the unnamed (in the Bible) dancing daughter of Herodias, wife of Herod, King of Judea.

''Sticky Fingers'' is the work of a female director (Catlin Adams), female screenwriters (Miss Adams and Melanie Mayron) and a mostly female cast (including supporting players like Eileen Brennan, Gwen Welles and Carol Kane), but it's less feminist than dizzily feminine. The two leading characters, struggling musicians sharing a picturesquely shabby downtown flat, are as bubble headed as they can be. This is especially apparent after fate sends a suitcase full of money their way, courtesy of a drug-dealing friend (Loretta Devine) who asks them to watch it for an indefinite period. What do they do about this windfall? They shriek, they squabble and then they shop. Helen Slater and Melanie Mayron, careening through the film in the kinds of zany ''Desperately Seeking Susan''-inspired outfits that are fun as long as they're on somebody else, play the blithe Hattie and Lolly at a screwball pitch. To enhance this, Miss Adams often directs them to talk frenetically at the same time, and she establishes the characters' charming eccentricity with cute shots of their unusual shoes. A lot of care has gone into the film's earring wardrobe, too. So ''Sticky Fingers'' tries too hard, but it does have a fundamental good-naturedness that comes through.

LEAD: GREEN CITY IN THE SUN. By Barbara Wood. (Random House, $19.95.) An interesting tale of Africa in the stormy days before independence is buried under about 300 pages of excess verbiage and extraneous characters in this new novel by the author of ''Domina'' and ''Vital Signs.'' In ''Green City in the Sun,'' Barbara Wood chronicles life in Kenya from 1919 to the present through the experiences of two families, the English Trevertons and the African Mathenges.

LEAD: To the Editor: This is a warning to European travelers: Check carefully before renting a car, especially on a short-term basis. We rented a deluxe car from Hertz in Paris for a two-day trip to the Loire Valley. It cost almost $600, based on the five-day, unlimited-mileage rate (which was cheaper than the daily rate with mileage -about 400 miles - added) and 33Y percent tax.

LEAD: Mary Cunniff, a daughter of Dr. Charles L. Cunniff of Jersey City and the late Margaret Norton Cunniff, was married yesterday to Barry Rawlinson, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Rawlinson of Hove, England. Capt. Carl Ruthberg, a Salvation Army minister, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York.

LEAD: Purist music lovers - the kind who regard anything more grandiose than a chamber-music concert as borderline vulgarian -look with extreme suspicion on opera. Not only is it big and noisy and emotionally crude (they think), but it is inherently sullied by not being strictly music at all. Opera is a hybrid, a form of musical theater that partakes of both music and theater.
LEAD: AFTER 20 volunteers finished with her house in Norwalk, Dorothy Farington had not seen it looking so good in years.

LEAD: A Yankee Stadium mascot would be consistent with at least two other ways the Yankee management is already debasing the game: first, using the home run to sell beer during broadcasts and second, the traditional but painfully outdated use of excessive organ playing during the game, with a guaranteed rendition of the Campbell's Soup theme each time a
LEAD: New York teams don't need guys running around in chicken suits, or other crazy antics. JACK CHVAT Maplewood, N.J.

LEAD: DEVELOPERS, gentlemen farmers and other owners of woodlands who qualify for farmland tax breaks must begin working their acreage in earnest this year if they want to retain their special farmland status.
LEAD: WITH help from a Connecticut Congressman, another effort is being mounted to add a statue of a servicewoman to the Vietnam Memorial in Washington.
LEAD: The Fourth of July celebration on the Mall, the nation's birthday in the nation's capital. is the stuff that fireworks makers' dreams are made on.

LEAD: Hugo DePew, the protagonist of Jeffrey Kindley's mild little comedy ''St. Hugo of Central Park,'' is that stock literary figure, a poor misunderstood youth crushed by the evil material world. Any parallels between the life of Christ and the character's eventual martyrdom are purely intentional.

LEAD: Professional baseball managers often engage in lively debate with umpires, commonly questioning their eyesight and ancestry. They are forbidden, however, to lay angry hands upon them, as Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, did last weekend while vehemently disputing a play at first base.

LEAD: Since airline deregulation in 1978, traffic has almost doubled, putting strains on the system. An increase in near misses, allegations against the Boeing Company of poor quality control, and last month's damage to an Aloha Airlines jetliner, have intensified concern over safety. What changes will be made in the way the skies are regulated?

LEAD: Maureen Anne Walsh, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Walsh of Cumberland Center, Me., was married yesterday to Jonkheer Ferdinand Folef Hooft Graafland, a son of Lydia Z. Hooft Graafland-Stahl of Wassenaar, the Netherlands, and the late Jonkheer Folef Ferdinand Joan Hooft Graafland. The Rev. Willem Dyckmeester performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Dorpskerk in Wassenaar.

LEAD: DEFINING A SANDWICH IS ALMOST impossible. Two slices of bread surrounding a filling doesn't do it, since a sandwich can be open-faced, or triple-faced. A sandwich can be humble, as in a slice of meat loaf on toasted white bread; grand, such as a sliver of velvety smoked salmon with cucumbers and beluga caviar, or grandiose, as in a listing tower of meat, cheese, lettuce and vegetables.
LEAD: GOOD HEARTS By Reynolds Price. 275 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.
